awd_titl_txt: Rational Design of Surface Modified Nanoparticles for Modulation of Amyloid Protein Aggregation
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
The aggregation of amyloid proteins is involved in a wide range of processes including the pathogenesis of numerous diseases (Alzheimer's disease, type 2 diabetes, etc.) as well as in biofouling associated with applications such as food production or water purification. The development of tools to prevent or slow this aggregation would thus be important in both therapeutics and industrial processes.  The main goal of this work is to develop a platform for the rational design of nanoparticles capable of modulating amyloid protein aggregation.  By coupling experiments and molecular modeling, this project will develop a novel description of the complex interactions that occur at the interface of biological environments and synthetic materials.  This theory can then be applied to predict the influence of nanoparticle-protein interactions upon amyloid protein aggregation, thus representing a design platform.  By advancing our understanding of interactions between nanoparticles and amyloid proteins, we will be able to rationally design nanoparticles for treating debilitating diseases, reduce unwanted biofouling, and facilitate industrial applications.  Graduate and undergraduate students participating in the project will acquire cutting-edge experimental techniques and frontier modeling approaches to train them for future careers in these areas.

Technical Description
The proposed research considers surface modified nanoparticles for the modulation of amyloid protein aggregation, which plays a deleterious role in disease and industrial processes. Recently, nanoparticles have emerged as attractive tools for selective protein interactions. Nanoparticle surface properties, size, and shape can be accurately controlled, and therefore nanoparticles provide an ideal tunable platform to modulate amyloid protein aggregation. The main goal of this work is to couple experiments and molecular modeling to develop a novel description of the complex coupling of interactions that occur at the interface of biological environments and synthetic materials.  These interactions can be subsequently used for the rational design of nanoparticles for modulation of amyloid protein aggregation. The research is guided by the central hypothesis that nanoparticle-induced changes in the local solution environment drive their ability to influence amyloid protein aggregation.  The coupling of experiments and modeling will provide the fundamental understanding needed to create design platforms for building nanostructured biomaterial interfaces that influence protein aggregation.  First, fully atomistic molecular simulations will be used in conjunction with detailed molecular theory to describe the local solution environment.  Second, a molecular thermodynamic model of amyloid protein aggregation will be implemented.  Finally, molecular level theories for nanoparticles and amyloid proteins will be coupled to quantify how a single nanoparticle influences local solution conditions to affect the stability of aggregates.  This coupled model will be used to rationally design and synthesize surface modified nanoparticles to experimentally evaluate their predicted effects on amyloid protein aggregation.  Agreement between experimental data and theoretical predictions will substantiate the proposed hypothesis.
The collaborative nature of the research environment created in this project will be exploited to promote biomedical engineering education within both research and classroom settings.  The proposed research will establish a summer undergraduate research internship in which students will complete complementary computational and experimental research tasks. To introduce this research area to pre-college students, a design-based module will be developed that familiarizes students with the concepts of biomaterial design for applications in protein aggregation. Together, these efforts will provide both undergraduate and pre-college students with an understanding of how engineering technologies can facilitate the control of biological phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW

The aggregation of monomeric protein into filamentous structures, known as amyloid fibrils, has wide-reaching implications, ranging from the prevention of unwanted amyloid aggregates in both disease pathogenesis and bioprocesses to the control of amyloid aggregation for the bottom-up assembly of nanowires and nanotubes. Recently, nanoparticles have emerged as attractive tools for selective protein interactions. Nanoparticle surface properties, size, and shape can be accurately controlled, and therefore nanoparticles provide an ideal tunable platform to modulate amyloid aggregation. This work coupled experiments and molecular level theory to develop a novel description of the complex coupling of interactions that occur at the interface of biological environments and synthetic materials, which can be subsequently used for the rational design of surface modified nanoparticles for modulation of amyloid protein aggregation.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The funded research has been guided by the central hypothesis that nanoparticle-induced changes in the local solution environment drive their ability to influence amyloid protein aggregation.

The experimental focus of the research designed and synthesized a library of gold nanospheres presenting end-tethered polyacids, which differed in nanoparticle diameter and polyacid length. Subsequently, these nanoparticles were assessed for their physical characteristics and the effect of each nanoparticle within the library on aggregation of amyloid-beta protein was determined. Ultimately, properties of the nanoparticles (diameter and polyacid length) were correlated with the effect on aggregation. Smaller nanoparticles with intermediate polyacid lengths were found to be the best inhibitors.

The theoretical focus of the research developed molecular-level models for both the dimerization of amyloid-beta and the influence of polyacid chains on the surrounding aqueous environment. The model of amyloid-beta dimerization successfully captured changes in aggregation propensity with variations in solution ionic strength, pH, and temperature. The model of polyacid chains simulated a discrete shearable, stretchable, wormlike chain to both capture the behavior of long polymers and retain details of spatial electrostatics. These models were coupled to predict changes in the local solution conditions surrounding nanoparticles and how those changes influence amyloid aggregation. Those predictions were correlated with experimental measurements of the manner in which nanoparticles impact amyloid-beta aggregation.

By coupling experimental and theoretical approaches, we can predict behavior of amyloid-beta in the presence of difference surface-modified nanoparticles, thus facilitating rational design of future nanoparticles inhibitors.

BROADER IMPACTS

These studies have generated a platform for rational design of nanoparticle modulators of amyloid aggregation. This platform will assist the design of inhibitors to prevent or control protein aggregation within pharmaceutical processes, disease therapeutics, and nanomaterial synthesis. Specifically, the protein selected for study, the amyloid-beta protein, is associated with Alzheimer’s disease. Current FDA-approved therapies for Alzheimer’s disease only alleviate symptoms. Disease modifying therapies, including inhibition of amyloid aggregation, will be vital to developing therapeutic strategies that halt disease progression.

Research was also coupled with biomedical engineering education in a research setting. Three undergraduate students and two graduate students conducted independent research projects associated with this funded research. These students presented their research at numerous regional and national meetings. Two of the undergraduate students have gone on to pursue graduate degrees, and one has enrolled in medical school. Both graduate students obtained jobs in the biotechnology industry.
